Dear CAROL EVELYN-FRISKE BANKS:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code PA 116 -722.120(1)(c)
Title Investigation, Inspection, and Examination of conditions, books,
records, and reports
Rule Code & The department may investigate, inspect, and examine conditions
Section of a childcare organization and may investigate and examine
Description books and records of the licensee. The licensee shall cooperate
1

with the department’s investigation, inspection, and examination
by doing all of the following:
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the department,
and encouraging witnesses, such as staff and household
members, to provide accurate and truthful information to the
department.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency terminated a staff member after they discovered the
staff member falsified files and documented home visits that never
actually occurred.
Investigation Interviews
Chief Administrator was interviewed by phone on 11/21/2024.
She reported someone from Branch County DHHS informed
Foster Care Supervisor that Foster Care Worker had not been
visiting with Youth A in the foster home. It was reported the last
visit that took place was a brief interaction between Foster Care
Worker and Youth A in Youth A’s therapist’s parking lot; however,
Foster Care Worker documented in the case record the visit took
place in the foster home. This resulted in Foster Care Supervisor
and Foster Care Worker reviewing the case records of youths on
Foster Care Worker’s caseload and contacting foster parents to
verify if documented visits in their homes took place. Chief
Administrator stated there were multiple visits documented in case
records and for which Youth A claimed mileage that foster parents
reported did not occur. Chief Administrator stated Foster Care
Worker’s employment has been terminated.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed by phone on
11/21/2024. She reported Foster Care Worker worked at the
agency for a little over a year. Foster Care Supervisor was made
aware by staff at Branch County DHHS that Foster Care Worker
conducted a visit with Youth A in Youth A’s therapist’s parking lot
and not in the foster home in October of 2024. Foster Care
Supervisor stated Foster Care Worker had documented in the
case record that visit took place in the home. Chief Administrator
called Youth A’s foster parents who confirmed the visit did take
place in a parking lot and implied it has happened before. Since
that time, Foster Care Supervisor and Chief Administrator have
contacted the foster parents for all of the youths on Foster Care
Worker’s caseload and they have all reported not having seen
Foster Care Worker in a while and there have been months when
visits in their home did not occur, but none of them gave specifics.
Foster Care Supervisor stated Foster Care Worker would provide
her with dates she had seen youths during every supervision held.
2

Foster Care Worker would then document those visits in the
youths’ case records and request mileage for those home visits.
Foster Care Supervisor stated none of the foster parents told her
Foster Care Worker wasn’t conducting monthly visits until Foster
Care Supervisor and Chief Administrator reached out to them.
MDHHS Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via video
conferencing on 12/19/2024. She reported being told by the
MDHHS staff monitoring the case, MDHHS Foster Care Worker,
monthly visits with Youth A in her foster home were not
documented for two consecutive months. MDHHS Supervisor
reported there were multiple meetings with Foster Care Worker
and Foster Care Supervisor about the case as it appeared Foster
Care Worker did not like Youth A’s foster parents and was not
working well with them. Due to the missing face to face contacts,
MDHHS Foster Care Supervisor asked Foster Care Supervisor to
conduct a visit with Youth A, in her foster home, in October of
2024. MDHHS Foster Care Supervisor stated the case has been
returned to MDHHS for direct care and MDHHS Foster Care
Worker is now assigned to the case.
MDHHS Foster Care Worker was interviewed by phone on
12/19/2024. She reported having been assigned as the monitor on
the case prior to having been assigned as the direct care worker.
She stated in September she noticed there were no face to face
with the youth in the foster home entered into the case record for
the month. MDHHS Worker spoke to Youth A’s foster parent who
reported only having seen Foster Care Worker for approximately 3
minutes in a parking lot on September 24, 2024. She stated
Foster Care Worker was there with another worker and youth and
only said “hi” to Youth A when she saw her in the parking lot. No
other visits occurred with Youth A that month.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• The following case contacts were entered by Foster Care
Worker in Youth A’s case record:
6/27/2024 – Announced visit in foster home
7/31/2024 Face to Face visit with youth
8/29/2024 – Visit in foster home
9/10/2024 - Worker at foster home for 1-1.5 hours
9/24/2024 - Draft contact documenting face to face at foster home
for 1-1.5 hours
10/16/2024 face to face with family at foster home 1-1.5 hours
• Text message between MDHHS Foster Care Worker and
Youth A’s foster parent in which MDHHS Foster Care
Worker asked if Foster Care Worker visited the foster home
3

in September. Youth A’s foster parent responded “no”
adding Foster Care Worker was supposed to attend Youth
A's medication review in September but did not. Youth A’s
Foster Parent saw Foster Care Worker in the parking lot
after the appointment. Foster Care Worker told her she was
running late and spoke with Youth A for approximately 3
minutes in the parking lot. No visit to the foster home was
made in September.
Analysis A violation is established due to Youth A’s case record including
information that is not truthful or accurate as visits with a youth in
her foster home that did not occur are documented to have
occurred.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
